segment.source: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network (Windows 10)
segment.target: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network (Windows 10)

segment.source: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network
segment.target: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network

segment.source: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network
segment.target: Isolating Windows Store Apps on Your Network

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: When you add new devices to your network, you may want to customize your Windows Firewall configuration to isolate the network access of the new Windows Store apps that run on them.
segment.target: When you add new devices to your network, you may want to customize your Windows Firewall configuration to isolate the network access of the new Windows Store apps that run on them.

segment.source: Developers who build Windows Store apps can declare certain app capabilities that enable different classes of network access.
segment.target: Developers who build Windows Store apps can declare certain app capabilities that enable different classes of network access.

segment.source: A developer can decide what kind of network access the app requires and configure this capability for the app.
segment.target: A developer can decide what kind of network access the app requires and configure this capability for the app.

segment.source: When the app is installed on a device, appropriate firewall rules are automatically created to enable access.
segment.target: When the app is installed on a device, appropriate firewall rules are automatically created to enable access.

segment.source: You can then customize the firewall configuration to further fine-tune this access if they desire more control over the network access for the app.
segment.target: You can then customize the firewall configuration to further fine-tune this access if they desire more control over the network access for the app.

segment.source: For example, a developer can decide that their app should only connect to trusted local networks (such as at home or work), and not to the Internet.
segment.target: For example, a developer can decide that their app should only connect to trusted local networks (such as at home or work), and not to the Internet.

segment.source: In this way, developers can define the scope of network access for their app.
segment.target: In this way, developers can define the scope of network access for their app.

segment.source: This network isolation prevents an app from accessing a network and a connection type (inbound or outbound) if the connection has not been configured for the app.
segment.target: This network isolation prevents an app from accessing a network and a connection type (inbound or outbound) if the connection has not been configured for the app.

segment.source: Then the network administrator can customize the firewall to further restrict the resources that the app can access.
segment.target: Then the network administrator can customize the firewall to further restrict the resources that the app can access.

segment.source: The ability to set and enforce these network boundaries ensures that apps that get compromised can only access networks where they have been explicitly granted access.
segment.target: The ability to set and enforce these network boundaries ensures that apps that get compromised can only access networks where they have been explicitly granted access.

segment.source: This significantly reduces the scope of their impact on other apps, the device, and the network.
segment.target: This significantly reduces the scope of their impact on other apps, the device, and the network.

segment.source: In addition, apps can be isolated and protected from malicious access from the network.
segment.target: In addition, apps can be isolated and protected from malicious access from the network.

segment.source: When creating new Windows Store apps, a developer can define the following network capabilities for their app:
segment.target: When creating new Windows Store apps, a developer can define the following network capabilities for their app:

segment.source: HomeWork Networking
segment.target: HomeWork Networking

segment.source: Provides inbound and outbound access to intranet networks that the user has designated as a home or a work network, or if the network has an authenticated domain controller.
segment.target: Provides inbound and outbound access to intranet networks that the user has designated as a home or a work network, or if the network has an authenticated domain controller.

segment.source: Internet (Client)
segment.target: Internet (Client)

segment.source: Provides outbound access to the Internet and untrusted networks, such as airports and coffee shops (for example, intranet networks where the user has designated the network as Public).
segment.target: Provides outbound access to the Internet and untrusted networks, such as airports and coffee shops (for example, intranet networks where the user has designated the network as Public).

segment.source: Most apps that require Internet access should use this capability.
segment.target: Most apps that require Internet access should use this capability.

segment.source: Internet (Client and Server)
segment.target: Internet (Client and Server)

segment.source: Provides inbound and outbound access to the Internet and untrusted networks, such as airports and coffee shops.
segment.target: Provides inbound and outbound access to the Internet and untrusted networks, such as airports and coffee shops.

segment.source: This capability is a superset of the Internet (Client) capability, and Internet (Client) does not need to be enabled if this capability is enabled.
segment.target: This capability is a superset of the Internet (Client) capability, and Internet (Client) does not need to be enabled if this capability is enabled.

segment.source: Proximity
segment.target: Proximity

segment.source: Provides near-field communication (NFC) with devices that are in close proximity to the device.
segment.target: Provides near-field communication (NFC) with devices that are in close proximity to the device.

segment.source: Proximity may be used to send files or connect with an application on a proximate device.
segment.target: Proximity may be used to send files or connect with an application on a proximate device.

segment.source: In this topic
segment.target: In this topic

segment.source: To isolate Windows Store apps on your network, you need to use Group Policy to define your network isolation settings and create custom Windows Store app firewall rules.
segment.target: To isolate Windows Store apps on your network, you need to use Group Policy to define your network isolation settings and create custom Windows Store app firewall rules.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Step 1: Define your network
segment.target: Step 1: Define your network

segment.source: Step 2: Create custom firewall rules
segment.target: Step 2: Create custom firewall rules

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: A domain controller is installed on your network, and your devices are joined to the Windows domain.
segment.target: A domain controller is installed on your network, and your devices are joined to the Windows domain.

segment.source: Your Windows Store app is installed on the client device.
segment.target: Your Windows Store app is installed on the client device.

segment.source: The Remote Server Administration Tools (RSAT) are installed on your client device.
segment.target: The Remote Server Administration Tools (RSAT) are installed on your client device.

segment.source: When you perform the following steps from your client device, you can select your Windows Store app when you create Windows Firewall rules.
segment.target: When you perform the following steps from your client device, you can select your Windows Store app when you create Windows Firewall rules.

segment.source: Note: You can install the RSAT on your device running Windows 10 from the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: Note: You can install the RSAT on your device running Windows 10 from the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: Step 1: Define your network
segment.target: Step 1: Define your network

segment.source: The HomeWork Networking capability enables access to intranet resources.
segment.target: The HomeWork Networking capability enables access to intranet resources.

segment.source: Administrators can use Group Policy settings to define the scope of the intranet.
segment.target: Administrators can use Group Policy settings to define the scope of the intranet.

segment.source: This ensures that Windows Store apps can access intranet resources appropriately.
segment.target: This ensures that Windows Store apps can access intranet resources appropriately.

segment.source: A network endpoint is considered part of the HomeWork Network if:
segment.target: A network endpoint is considered part of the HomeWork Network if:

segment.source: It is part of the local subnet of a trusted network.
segment.target: It is part of the local subnet of a trusted network.

segment.source: For example, home users generally flag their network as Trusted.
segment.target: For example, home users generally flag their network as Trusted.

segment.source: Local devices will be designated as such.
segment.target: Local devices will be designated as such.

segment.source: A device is on a network, and it is authenticated to a domain controller.
segment.target: A device is on a network, and it is authenticated to a domain controller.

segment.source: Endpoints within the intranet address space are considered private.
segment.target: Endpoints within the intranet address space are considered private.

segment.source: Endpoints within the local subnet are considered private.
segment.target: Endpoints within the local subnet are considered private.

segment.source: The device is configured for DirectAccess, and the endpoint is part of the intranet address space.
segment.target: The device is configured for DirectAccess, and the endpoint is part of the intranet address space.

segment.source: The intranet address space is composed of configured Active Directory sites and subnets, and it is configured for Windows network isolation specifically by using Group Policy.
segment.target: The intranet address space is composed of configured Active Directory sites and subnets, and it is configured for Windows network isolation specifically by using Group Policy.

segment.source: You can disable the usage of Active Directory sites and subnets by using Group Policy by declaring that your subnet definitions are authoritative.
segment.target: You can disable the usage of Active Directory sites and subnets by using Group Policy by declaring that your subnet definitions are authoritative.

segment.source: Any proxies that you configure or that are automatically configured with proxy autoconfiguration (by using Web Proxy Auto-Discovery (WPAD) protocol) are exempt from the intranet zone.
segment.target: Any proxies that you configure or that are automatically configured with proxy autoconfiguration (by using Web Proxy Auto-Discovery (WPAD) protocol) are exempt from the intranet zone.

segment.source: You can add proxy addresses by using Group Policy.
segment.target: You can add proxy addresses by using Group Policy.

segment.source: All other endpoints that do not meet the previously stated criteria are considered endpoints on the Internet.
segment.target: All other endpoints that do not meet the previously stated criteria are considered endpoints on the Internet.

segment.source: To configure a GPO that defines your intranet address space
segment.target: To configure a GPO that defines your intranet address space

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc) and edit the Default Domain Policy.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc) and edit the Default Domain Policy.

segment.source: From the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Administrative Templates, expand Network, and click Network Isolation.
segment.target: From the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Administrative Templates, expand Network, and click Network Isolation.

segment.source: In the right pane, double-click Private network ranges for apps.
segment.target: In the right pane, double-click Private network ranges for apps.

segment.source: In the Private network ranges for apps dialog box, click Enabled.
segment.target: In the Private network ranges for apps dialog box, click Enabled.

segment.source: In the Private subnets text box, type the private subnets for your intranet, separated by commas if necessary.
segment.target: In the Private subnets text box, type the private subnets for your intranet, separated by commas if necessary.

segment.source: For example, if the Contoso intranet is defined as 10.0.0.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0, you would type 10.0.0.0/24 in the Private subnets text box.
segment.target: For example, if the Contoso intranet is defined as 10.0.0.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0, you would type 10.0.0.0/24 in the Private subnets text box.

segment.source: Double-click Subnet definitions are authoritative.
segment.target: Double-click Subnet definitions are authoritative.

segment.source: If you want the subnet definitions that you previously created to be the single source for your subnet definition, click Enabled.
segment.target: If you want the subnet definitions that you previously created to be the single source for your subnet definition, click Enabled.

segment.source: Otherwise, leave the Not Configured default so that you can add additional subnets by using local settings or network isolation heuristics.
segment.target: Otherwise, leave the Not Configured default so that you can add additional subnets by using local settings or network isolation heuristics.

segment.source: To configure the proxy addresses for the intranet and Internet
segment.target: To configure the proxy addresses for the intranet and Internet

segment.source: Double-click Internet proxy servers for apps.
segment.target: Double-click Internet proxy servers for apps.

segment.source: Click Enabled, and then in the Domain Proxies text box, type the IP addresses of your Internet proxy servers, separated by semicolons.
segment.target: Click Enabled, and then in the Domain Proxies text box, type the IP addresses of your Internet proxy servers, separated by semicolons.

segment.source: Double-click Intranet proxy servers for apps.
segment.target: Double-click Intranet proxy servers for apps.

segment.source: Click Enabled, and then in the IP address text box, type the IP addresses of your intranet proxy servers, separated by semicolons.
segment.target: Click Enabled, and then in the IP address text box, type the IP addresses of your intranet proxy servers, separated by semicolons.

segment.source: Double-click Proxy definitions are authoritative.
segment.target: Double-click Proxy definitions are authoritative.

segment.source: If you want the proxy definitions that you previously created to be the single source for your proxy definition, click Enabled.
segment.target: If you want the proxy definitions that you previously created to be the single source for your proxy definition, click Enabled.

segment.source: Otherwise, leave the Not Configured default so that you can add additional proxies by using local settings or network isolation heuristics.
segment.target: Otherwise, leave the Not Configured default so that you can add additional proxies by using local settings or network isolation heuristics.

segment.source: Step 2: Create custom firewall rules
segment.target: Step 2: Create custom firewall rules

segment.source: Windows Store apps can declare many capabilities in addition to the network capabilities discussed previously.
segment.target: Windows Store apps can declare many capabilities in addition to the network capabilities discussed previously.

segment.source: For example, apps can declare capabilities to access user identity, the local file system, and certain hardware devices.
segment.target: For example, apps can declare capabilities to access user identity, the local file system, and certain hardware devices.

segment.source: The following table provides a complete list of the possible app capabilities.
segment.target: The following table provides a complete list of the possible app capabilities.

segment.source: Capability
segment.target: Capability

segment.source: Name
segment.target: Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Internet (Client)
segment.target: Internet (Client)

segment.source: internetClient
segment.target: internetClient

segment.source: Your outgoing Internet connection.
segment.target: Your outgoing Internet connection.

segment.source: Internet (Client Server)
segment.target: Internet (Client Server)

segment.source: internetClientServer
segment.target: internetClientServer

segment.source: Your Internet connection, including incoming unsolicited connections from the Internet The app can send information to or from your device through a firewall.
segment.target: Your Internet connection, including incoming unsolicited connections from the Internet The app can send information to or from your device through a firewall.

segment.source: You do not need to declare internetClient if this capability is declared.
segment.target: You do not need to declare internetClient if this capability is declared.

segment.source: Home\Work Networking
segment.target: Home\Work Networking

segment.source: privateNetworkClientServer
segment.target: privateNetworkClientServer

segment.source: A home or work network.
segment.target: A home or work network.

segment.source: The app can send information to or from your device and other devices on the same network.
segment.target: The app can send information to or from your device and other devices on the same network.

segment.source: Document Library Access
segment.target: Document Library Access

segment.source: documentsLibrary
segment.target: documentsLibrary

segment.source: Your Documents library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.
segment.target: Your Documents library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.

segment.source: The package can only access file types that are declared in the manifest.
segment.target: The package can only access file types that are declared in the manifest.

segment.source: Picture Library Access
segment.target: Picture Library Access

segment.source: picturesLibrary
segment.target: picturesLibrary

segment.source: Your Pictures library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.
segment.target: Your Pictures library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.

segment.source: Video Library Access
segment.target: Video Library Access

segment.source: videosLibrary
segment.target: videosLibrary

segment.source: Your Videos library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.
segment.target: Your Videos library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.

segment.source: Music Library Access
segment.target: Music Library Access

segment.source: musicLibrary
segment.target: musicLibrary

segment.source: Your Music library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.
segment.target: Your Music library, including the capability to add, change, or delete files.

segment.source: Default Windows Credentials
segment.target: Default Windows Credentials

segment.source: defaultWindowsCredentials
segment.target: defaultWindowsCredentials

segment.source: Your Windows credentials for access to a corporate intranet.
segment.target: Your Windows credentials for access to a corporate intranet.

segment.source: This application can impersonate you on the network.
segment.target: This application can impersonate you on the network.

segment.source: Removable Storage
segment.target: Removable Storage

segment.source: removableStorage
segment.target: removableStorage

segment.source: A removable storage device, such as an external hard disk, USB flash drive, or MTP portable device, including the capability to add, change, or delete specific files.
segment.target: A removable storage device, such as an external hard disk, USB flash drive, or MTP portable device, including the capability to add, change, or delete specific files.

segment.source: This package can only access file types that are declared in the manifest.
segment.target: This package can only access file types that are declared in the manifest.

segment.source: Shared User Certificates
segment.target: Shared User Certificates

segment.source: sharedUserCertificates
segment.target: sharedUserCertificates

segment.source: Software and hardware certificates or a smart card, which the app uses to identify you.
segment.target: Software and hardware certificates or a smart card, which the app uses to identify you.

segment.source: This capability can be used by an employer, a bank, or government services to identify you.
segment.target: This capability can be used by an employer, a bank, or government services to identify you.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: location
segment.target: location

segment.source: Provides access to the user's current location.
segment.target: Provides access to the user's current location.

segment.source: Microphone
segment.target: Microphone

segment.source: microphone
segment.target: microphone

segment.source: Provides access to the microphone's audio feed.
segment.target: Provides access to the microphone's audio feed.

segment.source: Near-field Proximity
segment.target: Near-field Proximity

segment.source: proximity
segment.target: proximity

segment.source: Required for near-field communication (NFC) between devices in close proximity.
segment.target: Required for near-field communication (NFC) between devices in close proximity.

segment.source: NFC can be used to send files or connect with an app on a proximate device.
segment.target: NFC can be used to send files or connect with an app on a proximate device.

segment.source: Text Messaging
segment.target: Text Messaging

segment.source: sms
segment.target: sms

segment.source: Provides access to text messaging functionality.
segment.target: Provides access to text messaging functionality.

segment.source: Webcam
segment.target: Webcam

segment.source: webcam
segment.target: webcam

segment.source: Provides access to the webcam's video feed.
segment.target: Provides access to the webcam's video feed.

segment.source: Other devices (represented by GUIDs)
segment.target: Other devices (represented by GUIDs)

segment.source: GUID
segment.target: GUID

segment.source: Includes specialized devices and Windows Portable Devices.
segment.target: Includes specialized devices and Windows Portable Devices.

segment.source: You can create a Windows Firewall policy that is scoped to a set of apps that use a specified capability or scoped to a specific Windows Store app.
segment.target: You can create a Windows Firewall policy that is scoped to a set of apps that use a specified capability or scoped to a specific Windows Store app.

segment.source: For example, you could create a Windows Firewall policy to block Internet access for any apps on your network that have the Documents Library capability.
segment.target: For example, you could create a Windows Firewall policy to block Internet access for any apps on your network that have the Documents Library capability.

segment.source: To block Internet access for any apps on your network that have the Documents Library capability
segment.target: To block Internet access for any apps on your network that have the Documents Library capability

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc).
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc).

segment.source: In the left pane, right-click your domain name and click Create a GPO in this domain, and link it here.
segment.target: In the left pane, right-click your domain name and click Create a GPO in this domain, and link it here.

segment.source: Type a name for the GPO in the Name text box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Type a name for the GPO in the Name text box, and then click OK.

segment.source: Right-click the new GPO, and then click Edit.
segment.target: Right-click the new GPO, and then click Edit.

segment.source: In the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Windows Settings, expand Security Settings, expand Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security – LDAP://…
segment.target: In the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Windows Settings, expand Security Settings, expand Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security – LDAP://…

segment.source: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.
segment.target: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.

segment.source: Click Custom, and then click Next.
segment.target: Click Custom, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Next on the Program page, the Protocols and Ports page, and the Scope page.
segment.target: Click Next on the Program page, the Protocols and Ports page, and the Scope page.

segment.source: On the Action page, ensure that Block the Connection is selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Action page, ensure that Block the Connection is selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Profile page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Profile page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, type a name for your rule, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type a name for your rule, and then click Finish.

segment.source: In the right pane, right-click your new rule and click Properties.
segment.target: In the right pane, right-click your new rule and click Properties.

segment.source: Click the Local Principals tab, select the Only allow connections from these users check box, and then click Add.
segment.target: Click the Local Principals tab, select the Only allow connections from these users check box, and then click Add.

segment.source: Click Application Package Properties, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Application Package Properties, and then click OK.

segment.source: In the Choose Capabilities dialog box, click APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITYYour documents library, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Choose Capabilities dialog box, click APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITYYour documents library, and then click OK.

segment.source: Click the Scope tab under Remote IP addresses, and then click Add.
segment.target: Click the Scope tab under Remote IP addresses, and then click Add.

segment.source: Click Predefined set of computers, select Internet, and click OK.
segment.target: Click Predefined set of computers, select Internet, and click OK.

segment.source: This scopes the rule to block traffic to Internet devices.
segment.target: This scopes the rule to block traffic to Internet devices.

segment.source: Click the Programs and Services tab, and in the Application Packages area, click Settings.
segment.target: Click the Programs and Services tab, and in the Application Packages area, click Settings.

segment.source: Click Apply to application packages only, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Apply to application packages only, and then click OK.

segment.source: Important: You must do this to ensure that the rule applies only to Windows Store apps and not to other apps.
segment.target: Important: You must do this to ensure that the rule applies only to Windows Store apps and not to other apps.

segment.source: Desktop apps declare all capabilities by default, and this rule would apply to them if you do not configure it this way.
segment.target: Desktop apps declare all capabilities by default, and this rule would apply to them if you do not configure it this way.

segment.source: Click OK to close the Properties dialog box.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Properties dialog box.

segment.source: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.
segment.target: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.

segment.source: In the Group Policy Management snap-in, ensure that your new GPO is selected, and in the right pane under Security Filtering, select Authenticated Users.
segment.target: In the Group Policy Management snap-in, ensure that your new GPO is selected, and in the right pane under Security Filtering, select Authenticated Users.

segment.source: Click Remove, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Remove, and then click OK.

segment.source: Under Security Filtering, click Add.
segment.target: Under Security Filtering, click Add.

segment.source: Type domain computers in the text box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Type domain computers in the text box, and then click OK.

segment.source: Close the Group Policy Management snap-in.
segment.target: Close the Group Policy Management snap-in.

segment.source: Use the following procedure if you want to block intranet access for a specific media sharing app on your network.
segment.target: Use the following procedure if you want to block intranet access for a specific media sharing app on your network.

segment.source: To block intranet access for a specific media sharing app on your network
segment.target: To block intranet access for a specific media sharing app on your network

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc).
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management snap-in (gpmc.msc).

segment.source: In the left pane, right-click your domain name, and then click Create a GPO in this domain, and link it here.
segment.target: In the left pane, right-click your domain name, and then click Create a GPO in this domain, and link it here.

segment.source: Type a name for your GPO in the Name text box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Type a name for your GPO in the Name text box, and then click OK.

segment.source: Right-click your new GPO, and then click Edit.
segment.target: Right-click your new GPO, and then click Edit.

segment.source: From the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Windows Settings, expand Security Settings, expand Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and then click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security – LDAP://…
segment.target: From the Group Policy Management Editor, expand Computer Configuration, expand Policies, expand Windows Settings, expand Security Settings, expand Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and then click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security – LDAP://…

segment.source: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.
segment.target: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.

segment.source: Click Custom, and then click Next.
segment.target: Click Custom, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Next on the Program page, the Protocols and Ports page, and the Scope page.
segment.target: Click Next on the Program page, the Protocols and Ports page, and the Scope page.

segment.source: On the Action page, ensure Block the Connection is selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Action page, ensure Block the Connection is selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Profile page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Profile page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, type a name for your rule, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type a name for your rule, and then click Finish.

segment.source: In the right pane, right-click your new rule, and then click Properties.
segment.target: In the right pane, right-click your new rule, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Click the Local Principals tab, select the Only allow connections from these users check box, and then click Add.
segment.target: Click the Local Principals tab, select the Only allow connections from these users check box, and then click Add.

segment.source: Click Application Package Properties, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Application Package Properties, and then click OK.

segment.source: In the Choose Capabilities dialog box, click APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITYA home or work network, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Choose Capabilities dialog box, click APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITYA home or work network, and then click OK.

segment.source: Click the Programs and Services tab under Application Packages, and then click Settings.
segment.target: Click the Programs and Services tab under Application Packages, and then click Settings.

segment.source: Click Apply to this application package, select the app in the text box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Apply to this application package, select the app in the text box, and then click OK.

segment.source: Click OK to close the Properties dialog box.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Properties dialog box.

segment.source: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.
segment.target: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.

segment.source: In Group Policy Management, ensure that your new GPO is selected, and in the right pane under Security Filtering, select Authenticated Users, click Remove, and then click OK.
segment.target: In Group Policy Management, ensure that your new GPO is selected, and in the right pane under Security Filtering, select Authenticated Users, click Remove, and then click OK.

segment.source: Under Security Filtering, click Add.
segment.target: Under Security Filtering, click Add.

segment.source: Type domain computers in the text box and click OK.
segment.target: Type domain computers in the text box and click OK.

segment.source: Close Group Policy Management.
segment.target: Close Group Policy Management.

segment.target: See also
